titleStmt.title: The dodechedron of fortune; or, The exercise of a quick wit A booke so rarely and strangely composed, that it giueth (after a most admirable manner) a pleasant and ingenious answer to euery demaund; the like whereof hath not heretofore beene published in our English tongue. Being first composed in French by Iohn de Meum, one of the most worthie and famous poets of his time; and dedicated to the French King, Charles the fift, and by him, for the worth and raritie thereof, verie much countenanced, vsed, and priuiledged: and now, for the content of our countrey-men, Englished by Sr. W.B. Knight. The vse of the booke the preface annexed declareth.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DODECHEDRON OF FORTVNE; OR, THE EXERCISE OF A QVICK WIT.

A Booke ſo rarely and ſtrangely compoſed, that it giueth (after a moſt admirable manner) a pleaſant and ingenious anſwer to euery demaund; the like whereof hath not heretofore beene publiſhed in our Engliſh Tongue. Being firſt compoſed in French by IOHN de MEVM, one of the moſt worthie and famous Poets of his time; and dedicated to the French King, CHARLES the fift, and by him, for the worth and raritie thereof, verie much countenanced, vſed, and priuiledged:
And now, for the content of our Countrey-men, Engliſhed by Sr. W. B. Knight.

p.hi: The vſe of the Booke the Preface annexed declareth.

div.p: LONDON Printed by Iohn Pindley, for H. H. and S. M. and are to be ſold at his Shop in Paules Church-yard, at the Signe of the Ball. 1613.

div.head: THE FRENCH AVTHOR TO THE READER.
div.p:
THe Curious Superſtition of Ancients in old times, deſirous with too great Affectation to know Fortunes and Aduentures, cauſed them to inuent and diſcouer an infinite number,Diuerſities of diuinations. or manner, of diuinations, or deuiſes for the ſame. As ſome by the foure elemēts, whereof came the Geomantie, Piromantie, Hidromantie & Areomantie: Others by Animals, whereof came the Auſpices, Augures, & Aruſpices: Others by Idolatrous Sacrifices wherof proceeded the Arioleans, the Pythoniſſeans, Sorcerers, Vaticinateurs, falſe Prophets, & ſuch like: Others haue taken Argument or matter of Diuinatiō vpon the ſhape or delineaments of man, whereof proceeded the Phyſiognomie, Metoſcopie, and Chiromancie: others by Conſtellation and Superſtitious Annotations of Signes, and the houſes Celeſtiall, portending generally thereby things to come; as alſo particularly vpon the natiuitie of any perſon, the courſe and ſucceſſe of his life; Some alſo by numbers, whereof came a ſort of Pithagoriques: and ſome by the Letters of the Alphabet, or Poeticall verſes, as the Homeriques and Virgilians: Others by Figures, Caracters, and Inuocation of ſpirits, as
Magicians, Necromancians, and the Caballe of the Iewes. Beſides a number of waies and meanes by men and euill ſpirits, the moſt part of which hath beene moſt curiouſly ſought and publiſhed by the Rabelays in his Pantagoueliſme. And although that ieſtingly, as mockes, hee puts them out, yet neuer theleſſe hee ſpeaketh not without a purpoſe and meaning. There is alſo yet another kinde of diuination that hath beene vſed,The Antiquity of lots. and that is by lottes, the which hath not beene deemed ſo ill and pernicious, as thoſe aboue named. For wee may finde that ſome of the auncient fathers did vſe to caſt lots for the finding out of matters in queſtion and doubt: And it is alſo found in the Ancient law, that Ioſuah vſed a lot to diſcouer him that had broken the Commandement of God, which lot fell vpon Acan, who confeſſed the fact, and was ſtoned to death. Likewiſe Saul vſed a lot, by the which he knew that Ionathan his ſon had made publike offence, for the which he wold haue put him to death, but the people ſaued him. The lot alſo fell on Ionas in flying from the Lord, who was thrown into the Sea and receaued by a Whale. And Saint Matthias was called and Elected by a lot to be an Apoſtle. And yet neuertheleſſe, ſuch kinde of lots, though the Ancient Fathers vſed them, is now iudicially reprooued and forbidden by the Canon of the Church, for that it might in time, grow to ſuperſtition, ſuch as that the faithfull might erre, and become idolatrous to the breach of the firſt commandement of God. But now againe to returne to our purpoſe; I finde that beſides the ſaid diuinations and lots, the ancients had diuers playes and Inuentions of Fortune for recreation & pleaſure,Plaies fortune. more then for any certainty or beleefe of trueth they had in them, the which were called plaies of Hazard and Aduenture: as theſe; The Teſſarae, Talorum, or Taxillorum, Doctohedron and Dodecahedron, the forme and faſhion of the figure
being ſundrie according to the diuerſity of the play: Not onely in the forme and ſquares of the dye, but likewiſe in the markes thereof. For in ſome there was prickes, or points, in other numerall figures, in ſome letters, and in ſome entire words, and celeſtiall Signes. For I haue ſeene the play called the Dodechedron, marked with the twelue Signes of the Zodiaque, in the throwing whereof they were perſwaded of ſome truth or certaine euent to their demaund. But I will not ſo perſwade you. Becauſe it cannot bee ſo, that theſe ſports of lots, dice, or ſuch like things of chance which we vſe, can bee ſuch or like thoſe which the ancients vſed, which they termed Teſſara and Talorum, notwithſtanding that the forme and figure be the like. And yet I am perſwaded that then with them, if there had not bin more matter of effect then in theſe we vſe, they had not beene ſo curious, nor vſed them ſo much. For it is found writnen in the life of the Emperour Claudius Caeſar, that he was ſo affectionated thereto, they cauſed to bee made, or himſelfe made a booke thereof. Alſo Auguſtus Caeſar was blamed for too much ſpending his time thereabouts. Plato in his dialogue of the Republique, doth there ſo eſteeme or extoll his play of Talorum, that hee maketh compariſon of it to the life of man. Therefore I will not take vpon mee to ſhew you the manner of Octohedron, an Dodecahedron as the ancients vſed them. For I muſt freely confeſſe vnto you, I am ignorant thereof. But for this play called Dodechedron of fortune,The Author of the play called Dodechedron. It is the meere inuention of one Maſter Iohn de Meum, one of the moſt famous French Poets of his time, the which hee dedicated and preſented to King Charles the fift then King of France, as I found by an Ancient Superſcription in the booke, when firſt I found it in a librarie of a friend of mine, who as well for the antiquitie, as the raritie of the ſame made great account thereof, keeping it being a written
booke euer ſecret to himſelfe, vntill that ouercome by my requeſt he was content to let it come abroad, & for that we wanted the knowledge and direction of the die being ſtrange, and the authors direction therein; wee were forced to ſeeke by the frequent communication of manie Doctors, for the vſe and diſcouerie thereof. The which by the onely induſtrious labour and learned Search of the worthie Maſter Iohn Moreau, Signieur of Monliger, both the vſe of the dye, and manner of the booke was found, as hereafter. Then firſt concerning the Authour Maſter Iohn de Meum, it is knowne that he was one of the moſt famous in the practiſe of the Mathematickes and Philoſophie of his time. And ſo concerning this his booke hee hath proceeded therein according to Aſtrologie, diuiding the queſtions into twelue chapters anſwerable to the twelue houſes celeſtiall, directly obſeruing the properties and ſignifications of them: for euerie chapter or rather houſe, hee hath propounded twelue demaunds or queſtions. And the booke contayning twelue replies or anſweres to euerie one, ſo that the Queſtions are in all 144. And the anſwers are to them in all 1728. If I ſhould hereupon take occaſion to deſcribe vnto you the Significations and properties of the celeſtiall houſes, and what planets raigneth in them, it would be ſuperfluous, tedious, and nothing at all fit or appertaining to this Subiect. It onely a little ſhall ſuffice mee to giue a taſte concerning the twelue houſes. And to begin with the firſt houſe which is called Horoſcope Angle of the orient Aſcendant, doth ſignifie the beginning of life and workes. The ſecond Succedent, ſignifying goods, trafficke, riches, and other things neceſſary for life. The third is termed Cadent, of the Aſcendent, portending Brothers, Siſters, coſens, kindred, aſſociates, Iudges, prelates, and ſuch like. The fourth is called the Angle of the earth, and ſo hath his ſignification to
fathers, poſſeſsions, houſes, hid Treaſures, and things ſecret. The fift houſe Succedent, being good fortune, ſignifying ſons and daughters, and their inclinations, Embaſſadors, Meſſingers, and profit to bee had by husbandrie or land. The ſixt houſe is called Cadent or euill fortune, noting baniſhment, ſeruitude, ſickeneſſe, falſe accuſations, and falſe witneſſes. The ſeauenth houſe is the Angle of the Occident, ſignifying mariages, quarrels, warre and things loſt. The eight houſe Succedent, the houſe of death, doth ſignifie ſorrow, troubles, long torments, poyſons, and qualities of death. The ninth houſe Cadent of the orient Angle, the houſe of God, doth ſignifie voiages, nauigations, faith, religion, ceremonies, diuinations, dreames, prodigies, and preſages, of diuine puniſhment. The tenth houſe called the heart of the heauens, or the Meridionall Angle, ſignifieth honour, dignities, gouernment of Kings, and great men. The cleauenth houſe being Succedent, Meridionall or the good Angle ſignifieth loue, companie, good Aduentures, fauour, aide, and ſuccors. The twelft and laſt houſe, called Cadent meridionall, or the euill ſpirit, doth ſignifie and denote Enemies, priſonings, Captiuities, vengeances, treaſons, deceauings, horſe to ſell, and a conſummation of the perſons inquired for, which twelue houſes the Ancients of olde time compiled together in theſe verſes following,
Natus, Vinci, Fratrem, Filium, Infernus, Vxorem,
Mors, Ambulat, Regnat, Fortuna, Incarceratur.

And thus it appeares that the Authour hath apropriated his queſtions to the propertie and qualities of theſe houſes, the which are very cunningly found by meanes of this dye, called Dodecaedron or Dodechedron. By the which in my iudgement this ſport is as ſubtil and ingenious, as the points of the geomancy. And that you may the better vnderſtand the faſhion and manner of the dye, it is a geometricall bodie, compoſed
of twelue faces, or ſides, which are Pentagones directlie equal, for otherwiſe it would neuer fall perfect:
• he forme
• f the Die. the which ſides or faces muſt bee ioined together cloſe and equally, as in the Figure following heere vnder appeares, the which cut in ſquares and then ioined together, carrying the one peece to the other, the body, called Dodecaedron or Dodechedron, will bee a geometricall figure, like vnto the leſſer peeces heere vnder.

This figure Dodechedron was much celebrated among the Ancients, comparing it vnto the round circle of the world or heauens. For like as in it is contained twelue Signes, diuided in 360. degrees, ſo this Dodechedron is compoſed of twelue faces, Pentagones, euerie one of which doth part or diuide it ſelfe into fiue Iſopleures, or triangles. Then thoſe againe ſubdiuided into ſix ſcalenes, which are triangles vnequall; Added together make iuſt 360. Scalenes. And thus being performed, this muſt be obſerued, for making the numbers on the dye, which is, that euer the 2. ſides oppoſed containe thirteene together, ſo that if the vndermoſt bee marked with eight, then the vppermoſt muſt be fiue: if with nine, then the other with foure: if with twelue, then the otherwith one, and ſo of the reſt.

The order of the playAnd now let vs beginne to ſhew you the order of the play, which will bee verie eaſie to doe, if you but obſerue and marke
the directions. Therefore you muſt firſt note that there is twelue leaues, vpon the which are twelue chapters containing the queſtions which any one may enquire for, being diuided into twelue ſpaces. Now if you deſire to know the anſwere or fortune of any of the ſaid queſtions, then obſerue preciſely in which of the ſaid houſes your demaund is in: for euery of the ſaid leaues are numbred at the top: then you muſt obſerue which of the ſpaces you haue choſen, for they bee numbred in the margent: then keeping in your memory the ſaid 2. numbers, firſt of the houſe, then of the queſtion; with theſe two numbers reſort to the table, which on the other ſide is prepared for that purpoſe, being ſquare containing twelue diuiſions, or ſpaces both waies, which is 144. ſpaces in all. Then you ſhall find another particular number written, which begins at the vpper corner on the left hand, & goes down thwart to the lower corner on the right hand, continuing his number to twelue, which are the numbers of the twelue houſes. So that firſt ſeek among theſe numbers the number of the houſe where your queſtion was, and there ſet your finger or marke it wel: then remember your ſecond figure as I told you before, which is the number of the ſpace in the houſes chapter, that your demaund is in. And with this beginne at your number where you held your finger, and what number ſoeuer it bee you muſt call it one, and ſo tell forward the ſquares toward the right hand, vntill you haue told to the number of your queſtion, or ſo manie ſquares, as the number of your queſtion was; Saying, 1. 2. 3. 4. and ſo forth, for you know the number of your queſtion cannot exceede twelue. Now if it chance that the houſe be in the middle of the ſquare, as is the figure 6. or 7. and that you haue told to the end of the laſt Square, you muſt then goe on to the other end of the ſame ſpace, continuing your telling vntill you come to the number of your queſtion, I meane,
to tell ſo many roomes or ſquares, as the number of your queſtion was. So that if your number were the 5. or 6. you muſt tell 5. or 6 ſquares from the number, counting it for one, till you come to your number, and there now againe reſt your finger,The vſe of the dye. for that you haue done with the firſt ſquare. And now for your chaunce throw the dye Dodechedron, and marke truly what number ſtands vppermoſt on the dye. And then in the table where you held your finger, ſay one, telling downewards in the ſpaces, as before you did thwart or ſidewaies betweene the lines, and ſo continue telling vntill you come to the number that was on the dye. And if you come to the bottome before you haue your number, goe vp to the vpper end in the ſame ſpace, continuing your telling till you come as is ſaid, to the number on the die. And there in that ſquare, where your number ends, marke the number or figures that you finde there, for that will be the number of the leafe or folio, where the anſwere of your demaund ſtands. And the number that was vpon the die, is the number of the verſe in that leafe, which will anſwere directly your demaund.
I haue choſen the ſeauenth houſe which pretendeth Marriages, and there the fift queſtion, which you ſhall find to be this following.

p.hi: Whether there be cauſe of Iealouſie or no.

div.p:
Here now you ſee as I told you before, the ſeauenth houſe, and the fift queſtoin. Now goe vnto your table for the ſeauenth houſe which you ſhall finde marked in the ſquare ouer ſeauentie nine, and now proceeding ſidewaies towards the right hand, call this Square of 79. but one, then tell 91. for 2. then 103. for 3. then 115. for 4. then 127. for 5. which is the number of your queſtion. And now vpon this number
put your finger, and throw the die Dodechedron, which chaunceth with eight vpon the top. And now againe beginne at your finger, or the number 127. deſcending downewards, telling 127. for 1. then 128. for 2. then 129. then 130. then 131. then 132. for 6. then being at the laſt, goe vp to the top to 121. for 7. and 122. for 8. which is the number you ſeeke for, therefore goe to the leafe 122. the 8. verſe which is there thus.

122
Be not Ielous nor miſdoubt not thy wife,
For ſhee ſhall be true all daies of her life.
8

By this example the reſt are eaſily practiſed to anſwere you truly your demaund. But how direct I cannot ſay, for the intent is only for pleaſure. So that if by chaunce it hit right and ſay true, yet adde not the more beleefe, for it is vnpoſſible but that in ſo many queſtions and replies, ſome muſt hit. And if alſo it be apparant amiſſe, be not offended, for the intent is only for pleaſure. And concerning the ſtrange words which are at the top of euery leafe. I know not the meaning nor what language they are, hauing found them in the firſt originall from the Authour, ſo that I eſteeme them inuented words, rather then to ſignifie any import. And becauſe I ſo found them I haue ſet them downe, leaſt any other might perchaunce finde more in them then I can. And ſo with my labours for thy pleaſure, and my good will to thy acceptance,

div.head: The Tranſlator to the Reader.
div.p: AS it is eaſie to imitate: So may the youngeſt Scholler of good vtterance, deliuer the learnedſt Oration, that euer was penned, by the graueſt and moſt eloquenteſt Orator. The painter alſo with ſmall skil may pomeis out his patterne, to make his picture like the principall. And ſo may any imboſſed forme be caſt in a mould, to ſhape the ſame as it was from the firſt hand in theſe ſlights. Some Commendations the doer may deſerue: Yet far from the merits of him, whoſe learned ſchoole was firſt the authour. But as Theſeus hauing conquered the Minotaur, remained incloſed in a laberinth, and thereby vnable to get out and manifeſt his victorie to the world: So my ſelfe hauing ſubdued ſloth, by reading, thought my victorie to be but vaine, vnleſſe I could come forth to encourage others by my ſucceſſe: wherefore with Theſeus, I haue but wound vp Ariadnes clew or bottome, and ſo proceeded by the threed, to tranſlate ſo neere as I could this moſt pleaſant and ingenious worke, written firſt by Mr. Iohn de Meum a famous French Poet, wiſhing it had rather bin by ſome other then by me perfected, whoſe learned skill and ſcope of words, might haue adorned the ſame, for the more pleaſant recreation to the Reader. But becauſe my intent was no farther then for the pleaſure of ſome my familiar friends, I only to giue them content, haue with ordinary phraſes performed the tranſlation the beſt I could, crauing therfore if it wander beyond my expectation, that then the gentle Reader will excuſe me, in my errors, and rather be ſilent, then reprochfully reproue me, confeſſing my ignorance, as alſo my profeſſion of a Souldier to be moſt vnfit to performe the ſame, as it is worthie for the inuention. And thus, friend and vnacquainted whoſoeuer, hoping thou wilt fauour me to my good meaning, I leaue my labours, and the ſport to thy good liking, and reſt,

lg.head: TO MEN.
lg.l: CAſt forth, my friend, the Dodechedron Dye;
If he hit truth 'twill moue thee to delight;
And if it chance that he doe tell a lye,
That is the ſport, for thee to laugh out right:
For but to ſport, and not for truth, 'twas pend
To giue content, and no man to offend.

lg.head: TO BOYES.
lg.l: YEt wanton Boyes, and Lads that doe lacke grace,
Let them not caſt, for all will here be ſhowne;
And what he ſaith, obſerue them in the face,
By broken browes vnhappie boyes are knowne.
But if they mend, the beſt is to forbeare them,
The Dye ſaith ſo, but onely for to feare them.

lg.head: TO SERVANTS.
lg.l: ANd Seruants that their Maiſters doe abuſe,
Let them take heed how here the Dye they throw,
For howſoeuer they their faults excuſe,
This booke their priu • e knaueries all doth know:
Yet honeſt ſeruants throw, and greatly care not
What ſo he ſaith, but caſt the Dye and ſpare not.

lg.head: TO MAIDES.
lg.l: ANd prettie Maides, to caſt the Dye forbeare,
For hee'll tell all, if you haue done amiſſe,
Your priuie loues, with whom, both when, and where:
Hee'll make it knowne and if you doe but kiſſe:
Yet bluſh not gyrles, but caſt couragiouſly,
If it chance ill, then ſweare it is a lye.

div.head: THE TABLE OF THE TVVELVE HOVSES.

lg.head: Beginning of life.
lg.l: 1 Whether nature hath ordained, or no, that the childe ſhall be of a good complexion.
2 Whether or no the childe ſhall bee deliuered ſound of bodie. And be withall of long life.

lg.head: Preſages of young ones.
lg.l: 3 Whether or no it ſhall bee of a good quicke ſpirit, and haue a good memorie.
4 Whether or no it ſhall pronounce and ſpeake plaine, and ſo prooue pleaſing in ſpeech.

lg.head: Naturall inclination.
lg.l: 5 Whether or no it ſhall be fit for ſtudie or other waies to be diſpoſed of.
6 What ſcience he ſhall be apteſt to learne and fitteſt to comprehend.
7 If in learning at the vniuerſitie then which of the arts he may beſt profeſſe.

lg.head: Of thoughts & cogitations.
lg.l: 8 If anie one ſtudie in his minde, whether his thoughts ſhall be good or bad.
9 Alſo whether the thoughts agree with the words or be diſſembled.
10 Whether or no you ſhall obtaine your deſire of what you wiſh. And in what ſpace it will be had.

lg.head: Workes begun.
lg.l: 11 If thou intend a worke whether it bee a proſperous time to begin or to ſtay yet.
12 If things begunne ſhall haue a good ſucceſſe and a proſperous end, or no.

lg.head: Of Inclination.
lg.l: 1 Whether your life ſhal be proſperous or no.
2 Whether you ſhall bee rich or no.

lg.head: Of Riches.
lg.l: 3 By what meane or profeſſion thou ſhalt bee rich and proſper beſt.
4 Whether thou ſhalt get riches in thy youth or in thine age.
5 Whether thy wealth ſhall bee by birth, by art or aduenture.

lg.head: Of Hope.
lg.l: 6 Whether thou ſhalt obtaine thy ſuite or hopes or no.
7 Whether, or no, thou ſhalt be enuied for thy riches.
8 Whether the profeſſion hee intends, or now vſeth, ſhalbe profitable, or no.

lg.head: Of Debts and Recoueries.
lg.l: 9 Whether, hauing lent thy money, or other thing, thou ſhalt recouer it againe, or no.
10 Whether a deſperat debtor ſhall recouer and content his creditors, or no.

lg.head: Of Liberalitie.
lg.l: 11 Whether one that is, or ſhall bee rich, will proue liberall, or no.
12 What ſhall bee his moſt delight that is rich, and wherein he will ſpend moſt.

lg.head: Of Brethrē.
lg.l: 1 Whether Brethren ſhall loue or no.
2 Which of the brethren ſhall liue longeſt.
3 Which of the breethren ſhall bee moſt fortunate.

lg.head: Of Societie & Company
lg.l: 4 Whether or no thy ſuppoſed friend & companion be a true friend.
5 Whether it ſhall prooue hurtfull to thee to keepe & frequent the company thou doſt or no.
6 Whether it be good now to part with company or as yet to ſtay or no.

lg.head: Of Iudges.
lg.l: 7 Whether the Iudge be vpright to doe equall Iuſtice to all or no.
8 Whether this Iudge being faultie ſhall be hated or no.

lg.head: Of Prelates
lg.l: 9 Whether the prelate or church-man be worthie of his place and dignitie, or no.
10 Whether hee ſhall religiouſly gouerne the Church, or no.

lg.head: Of ſucking Children.
lg.l: 11 Whether the nurſe that giues the child ſucke be a good nurſe and haue a good breſt, or no.
12 When it ſhall bee beſt weaning the childe from the nurſe.

lg.head: Fortune.
lg.l: 1 What ſhall be the euent of good or ill to any one.

lg.head: Of Fathers and ſucceſſion.
lg.l: 2 VVhether the reputed father be the right father of the child, or no.
3 VVhether the father ſhall liue long to bring vp the childe, or no.
4 VVhether he ſhall haue great poſſeſſions by heireſhip or purchaſe, or no.

lg.head: Of Fertillitie.
lg.l: 5 VVhether this yeere ſhall be proſperous for planting, or no.
6 VVhether fruites of the earth ſhall bee good cheape or deere this yeere,

lg.head: Of Building.
lg.l: 7 VVhether the time be good to begin a building, or no.
8 VVhether the building now ended bee well wrought and well founded, or no.
9 VVhether thy pretended purpoſes are to bee followed, or for a time forborne, or no.

lg.head: Of treaſure and ſecrets.
lg.l: 10 VVhether in the place where it is thought treaſure is hid, it be there or no.
11 VVhether the treaſure ſhall be found, and in what place it is.
12 VVhether a ſecret being kept cloſe ſhall be reuealed, and knowne, or no.

lg.head: Of getting Children.
lg.l: 1 VVhether the couple maried ſhall haue children together, or no.
2 VVhether of them is in fault if they haue no children.
3 VVhether the woman by her bignes be with childe, or no.
4 VVhether being with child it bee a ſonne or a daughter.

lg.head: The nature of children.
lg.l: 5 VVhether your childe ſhall be giuen to vertue or vice, or his pleaſure.
6 VVhether being a daughter ſhe ſhall be religious like a nunne, or to the world a wanton.

lg.head: Of play.
lg.l: 7 VVhat ſport is beſt to vſe for recreation.

lg.head: Of meſſengers.
lg.l: 8 VVhether the meſſenger to be imploid bee honeſt, or no.
9 VVhether the meſſenger ſhall diſcharge the errand giuen him in charge rightly, or no.

lg.head: Of newes
lg.l: 10 Whether the newes reported be true, or no.

lg.head: Of meſſages.
lg.l: 11 VVhether the contents of the letter tend to good or ill.
12 VVhether writing of loue, it ſhall bee beſt in proſe or verſe.

lg.head: Of Baniſhment.
lg.l: 1 Whether a baniſhed man ſhall bee reſtored, or no.

lg.head: Of Seruāts.
lg.l: 2 Whether the childe growing to age ſhall be free, or liue ſeruilely, or no.
3 Whether thy ſeruant bee truſtie and honeſt, or no.
4 Whether it bee good to take a ſeruant, and how to chuſe.
5 Whether the ſeruant by being honeſt and carefull, ſhall at laſt be a maſter or no.

lg.head: Of Sicknes & Phiſick.
lg.l: 6 Whether the diſeaſed ſhall recouer, or no.
7 Whether the diſeaſe or ſickneſſe ſhall bee long, or no.
8 Whether the Phiſition be a ſufficient skilfull practicioner, or no.
9 Whether it bee fitting thy complexion to take phiſicke, or no.
10 Whether the potion giuen by the Phiſition be good for the patient, or no.

lg.head: Of Coniurers.
lg.l: 11 Whether the ſuſpected be a ſorcerer, or no.

lg.head: Of Witneſſes.
lg.l: 12 Whether the witneſſe ſpeake truth, or no.

lg.head: Of Mariages.
lg.l: 1 Whether it be good for thee to marie, or no.
2 VVhether ſhall be thy beſt to marie a maide or a widow.
3 VVhether being maried thou ſhalt continue to loue, or no.
4 Whether the maried couple be loyal the one to the other, or no.
5 VVhether there be cauſe of ielouſie, or no.

lg.head: Of war and combats.
lg.l: 6 VVhether the child ſhal be addicted to armes and warres, or no.
7 Whether this yeere there ſhall bee peace or warre.
8 Whether the warres begunne ſhall bee ſhort or long, or cruell and bloodie.
9 Whether of the two now in controuerſie and to fight ſhall ouercome.

lg.head: Of traffick.
lg.l: 10 Whether it be good to buye or ſell much now, or no.

lg.head: Of things loſt.
lg.l: 11 VVhether the thing wanting ſhall bee had againe, or no.

lg.head: Of hunting.
lg.l: 12 VVhether the ſport of hunting or hawking be beſt for thee.

lg.head: Of death.
lg.l: 1 Whether the perſon you pretend or enquire for ſhall liue long, or die ſoone.
2 VVhether the partie you pretend ſhall die young, or old.
3 Whether the partie you pretend ſhall liue long and die at home, or in a ſtrange countrie.
4 Whether he ſhall die by ſickneſſe, ſword, or warre.
5 Whether by exceſſe and miſdemenor hee ſhall aduance his owne death, or no.

lg.head: Of abſents.
lg.l: 6 Whether that anie abſent or in exile, bee aliue, or no.
7 Whether his death being a ſouldier ſhall be in the fielde with honour, or no.

lg.head: Of death.
lg.l: 8 Whether of thoſe that now are talking ſhall die firſt.

lg.head: Of feare & poyſoning.
lg.l: 9 Whether the threpned be affraide and ſhalbe in ſuertie, or no.
10 Whether fearing poyſoning you may be ſafe or no.
11 Whether fearing thou art poyſoned, thou art or no.

lg.head: Choiſe of death.
lg.l: 12 If a man might chuſe, then what death were beſt to die.

lg.head: Of voyages.
lg.l: 1 Whether the iourney pretended ſhall ſafely be performed, or no.
2 Whether the ſhippe enquired for ſhall come ſafe, or no.
3 Whether one readie for a voyage by ſea ſhall ſcape the pyrates, or returne without taking, or no.

lg.head: Religion.
lg.l: 4 Whether he be fitte to bee made a religious Church man, or no.
5 Whether the maiden if ſhe might would be a nunne, or no.

lg.head: Hypocriſie.
lg.l: 6 Whether he bee religious or an Hypocrite, or no.
7 Whether he bee capable and fit for learning, or no.

lg.head: Significatiō of dreames.
lg.l: 8 Whether thy dreame be true, or no.
9 Whether thy dreame preſage good or ill.
10 Whether the preſages and ſignes ſignifie good or ill.

lg.head: Of diuination.
lg.l: 11 Whether by diuination thou ſhalt know the thing thou ſeekeſt, or no.

lg.head: Of iuſtice.
lg.l: 12 Whether iuſtice or peace ſhall floriſh, or no.

lg.head: Of preferment and credit.
lg.l: 1 Whether if thou deſire credit and preferment thou ſhalt obtaine it, or no.
2 Whether it be now good to ſeeke or ſue for any office, or no.
3 Whether thou ſhalt get credit and riches at home, or in forraine countries.
4 Whether it ſhall bee long or ſoone ere thy preferment beginne.
5 Whether thy honour or credit beeing loſt thou mayſt by deſerts recouer againe, or no.

lg.head: Of Princes ſeruice.
lg.l: 6 Whether it bee now good to vndertake the Princes ſeruice, or no.

lg.head: Of Kings.
lg.l: 7 Whether a Prince or a great man ſhall raigne long in honour, or no.
8 Whether he ſhall raigne in equitie and good iuſtice, or no.
9 Whether he ſhall be beloued of his ſubiects, or no.
10 Whether he ſhall bee oppreſt with warre, or haue peace, or no.
11 VVhether hee ſhall bee liberall and valiant, or no.
12 VVhether a King by ſucceſſion or election be beſt.

lg.head: Of loue.
lg.l: 1 VVhether this yeere to thee ſhall bee fortunate, or no.
2 VVhether thy hopes and expectation ſhal be, or no.
3 VVhether the louer ſhall enioy his loue, or no.
4 By what meanes hee may beſt worke to obtaine his loue.
5 VVhether the louer be beloued of his friend and loue, or no.
6 VVhether calling thee friend and loue, they diſſemble, or no.
7 VVhether loue begun ſhall laſt long, and what ſhall be the end.
8 VVhether of the two loue beſt, the one, or the other.

lg.head: Of friendſhippe.
lg.l: 9 VVhether thy profeſſed friend be ſo, or no.
10 Whether in thy declining ſtate thou ſhalt haue friends, or no.
11 Whether the rich, or poore mans loue bee more beſt or conſtant.

lg.head: Of fortune.
lg.l: 12 Whether it be thy time now of good fortune or no.

lg.head: Of enemies.
lg.l: 1 Whether are moſt thy friends or thy foes.
2 Whether he ſhall ouercome and get the better of his enemies, or no.

lg.head: Of law.
lg.l: 3 Whether of thy law matter thou ſhalt haue a good end, or no.
4 What is the beſt courſe to end the proces quickly.

lg.head: Of ſiege.
lg.l: 5 Whether the fort or caſtell beſeeged ſhall be got, or no.

lg.head: Of reuenge.
lg.l: 6 Whether it bee fit and good to reuenge a wrong, or no.

lg.head: Of priſoners.
lg.l: 7 Whether a priſoner ſhall get his inlargement, or no.

lg.head: Of ſorrow.
lg.l: 8 Whether ſorrow and griefe ſhall be aſſwaged by comfort, or no.

lg.head: Of deceit & coſenage.
lg.l: 9 Whether he that faine would and alſo hath a meanes to deceaue thee, ſhall or no.

lg.head: Of enuie.
lg.l: 10 Whether any neighbour or companion doe hate thee.

lg.head: Buying of horſes.
lg.l: 11 Whether the horſe that they would ſell thee is good and fit to buy, or no.

lg.head: Mans end.
lg.l: 12 Whether the laſt end of anie man ſhall bee good or euill.
WHere ſoeuer you change, it is vnderſtood,
Your ill complexion will neuer be good.
He ſhall to his credit all things ſo frame,
That none ſhall be able to touch his good name.
Thou ſhalt enioy thy loue at thy pleaſure,
And that verie ſoone, of this be thou ſuer.
By induſtrie and vertuous education,
He ſoone ſhall grow to great reputation.
She ſhall be good and chaſt in minde and all,
In what eſtate ſoeuer her befall.
Though the ſickneſſe be great with griefe and paine,
Yet ſhall it be returnd to health againe.
For warre which now is likely to be,
Good men ſhall endure the moſt penurie.
This vnlearned aſſe, is no doctor at all,
And in that art his ſkill is very ſmall.
He is not ſuch as thou doſt wiſh and craue,
To bring to paſſe the thing that thou wouldſt haue.
There is no thing that can turne to thy grace,
But onely this a bare and ſimple place.
This nurſe I ſee doth pleaſe my minde no whit,
Her milke is nought, and ſo ſhe is vnfitte.
The miſer ſlaue, a farthing will not ſpend,
For feare his goods, ſhould faile before his end.
His owne good nature doth him ſtill addreſſe,
To practiſe vertue, and ſuch like goodnes.
By his complexion he doth much incline,
To be of good nature, and ſo moſt ſanguine.
Of all his foes he ſhall ſee an ill end,
By the good aſſiſtance of his true friend.
For to obtaine it, it ſhall not be hard.
Yet take héede of falſhood leaſt that all be mard.
After long ſeruice, thou then ſhalt obtaine,
Preferment to honour, and ſo ſhalt remaine.
To ſeeme to be preciſe, is no other thought,
But a forlorne bodie, caſt off to nought.
Though that his bodie, in health doe remaine,
His ſpirit endureth great torture and paine.
Great Princes ſhall haue, by their great allyance,
Th'expulſing of Mars, and his worſt defyance.
This doctor in Theorique, and practiſe alſo,
Is better in proofe then outward in ſhow.
This meſſenger ſhall doe all thing at large,
Forgetting of nothing, that's giuen him in charge.
Of wealth and of treaſure, ther's ſtore of the ſame,
But looke well vnto it, you come not to blame.
This truely is ſhee for better or worſe,
That ſure will prooue a very good nurſe.
This nurſe is humorous, and ſo moſt fantaſticke,
And thereby her milke, will prooue moſt collerique.
He is moſt enclined, to aduentures ſtrange,
And ſo his eſtate, to pouerty ſhall change.
He ſhall be outragious, collericke and whott,
If that by reaſon, they temper him not.
All his enemies are mightie great and ſtrong,
And ſo his reſiſtance ſhall bring but more wrong.
Thou loſeſt but labour in ſo thy pretending,
Then ſome other where, expect a good ending.
He careth ſtill more for profit and gaine,
Then for honeſtie or friend, this is moſt certaine.
She ſhall loue better as all men may iudge,
An honeſt good man, then a miſerly drudge.
Maruell not at all, though tariance be long,
For he is detayned, and doth thee no wrong.
We are in great danger, by ſea and by land,
To haue great warres, as I vnderſtand.
As phiſicke vnfitting, no health thou ſhalt haue,
For he's but a foole, and an ignorant knaue.
He ſhall be thy contrarie, note this thing well,
And therefore thy ſecrets, ſée thou doe not tell.
Forbeare thou a little, and be ſo content,
But make no purſute, leaſt thou do repent.
I will enſure thee hee is there as yet,
But yet for to ſée, the time will not fit.
This hath milke good ſtore, and excellent good,
Thou canſt chuſe no better of fleſh nor of blood.
He lewdly ſpends all in vices of treachery,
As dicing, and carding, whoring, and lechery.
This good inclination, doth tend to no ill,
But lendeth & ſpendeth, with meane & good will.
By prudence, wiſedome, and good diſcretion,
He ſhall bée ſecret and of good condition.
After thy miſerie, thy labour, and paine,
Thou ſhalt heape vp freinds and be well againe.
Thy honour and fame ſhall grow vp ſo hie,
That thy great renowne ſhall liue immortally.
By nature and birth and good inclination,
She ſtill ſhall be apt to good education.
Beléeue not reports, nor be not diſmaide,
Hee's ſound in perſon, what euer is ſaide.
Peace and truce ſhall be, wars as now ſhall ſlacke.
For trouble ſpoyleth all, & brings our ſtate to wracke.
This man is ſkilfull, moſt wiſe and learned,
Sufficient in all, as well may be diſerned.
He ſhall full well performe his charge and meſſage,
If he be not ſurpriſ'd in ſome ſtrait paſſage.
To doe a meſſage diſcréetly and well,
I will you enſure that he ſhall excell.
There is ſtore of treaſure, I know that moſt true,
But how to finde it, I cannot tell you.
If of neceſſitie you will haue a nurſe,
Then paſſe ouer this, for you cannot haue a worſe.
He will endeuour all that euer he can,
To purchaſe the name of an honeſt man.
He ſhall of himſelfe be euer mutable,
And in both good & ill, prooue moſt variable.
Thy magnimious minde armed with patience,
Shall on thy enemies bring deſtroying vengeance.
This doting nidiot by his fooliſh deſart,
Shall of his faire loue at all haue no part.
If otherwiſe thou doeſt not ſoone prepare,
Neither honour nor wealth will come to thy ſhare.
Thence ſhall ſhe increaſe with reſolute courage,
To ſerue God deuoutly in honourable mariage.
Leaue off from ſéeking to ſpurne or to kicke,
For if death come not, yet is he very ſicke.
The wars are likely to be of ſuch ſort,
That the pooreſt people ſhall lie in the durt.
By boaſting and bragging he thinkes for to gaine,
With more words then wit, when both are but vaine.
He is aduiſed, graue, modeſt, and wiſe.
As is moſt apparent in all mens eyes.
By wiſe good deſeruings and vertuous parts,
He ſhall gaine the loue of moſt peoples hearts.
There was treaſure hidden as ſome men doe ſay,
But now by peece-meale t'is all ſtolne away.
Margery good cow, neither good nor bad,
A little ſope milke, is all may be had.
He ſpends all he hath in toyes and in bables,
In cardes and in dice, and in playing at tables.
His verie behauiour as all men ſhall prooue,
Shall gaine him great wealth reputation and loue.
In reſpect of his owne moſt vertuous minde,
All loue ſhall increaſe and quarrels ſhall end.
His conſtant minde, that hath ſo long endured,
Hath loue and pittie from his friends procured.
His moſt noble minde deſpiſing of ſhame,
Hath wonne him great credit and eternall fame.
By inclination he ſhall prooue a better dauncer,
Then to art or learning to be an aduancer.
As in perfect health he can endure no ill.
But ſhall haue good fortune attend on him ſtill.
God ſhall giue vs by his omnipotence,
This yeere plentie if we haue patience.
This yeere you ſhall haue neither troubles nor war.
But that euery one for profit may prepare.
This medicine or Phiſition hath no great ſkill,
Vnable to helpe, but comming to kill.
He is ſufficient in euerie part,
And ſhall end thy buſineſſe, to thy owne heart.
There is treaſure which ſeeking may be found,
But it lyeth hid very déepe in the ground.
In all mens eyes ſhe doth froward appeare,
Being rude, fooliſh, and of no good manner.
He ſhall more willingly his good ſtill ſpend,
In releeuing the poore then abroad to lend.
This partie ſhall doe all things at leaſure,
But euer addicted to take his owne pleaſure.
By his ſweete word and well plaſt perſwaſion,
He ſhall obtaine where he hath occaſion.
Reare vp thy ſpirit, be pleaſed and ſo reioyce,
For fate hath ſaid thou ſhalt enioy thy choiſe.
By vertuous labours in verie ſhort ſpace,
Thou ſhalt enioy an honourable place.
If that ſhe haue vowed for to liue chaſt,
The end will prooue ill, and her promiſe diſplaſt.
Whether he be dead or with ſickneſſe tormented,
Suppoſe you the beſt, and ſo be contented.
If that in ſhort ſpace he doe not returne,
His part is full plaid, and you may well mourne.
It is in war that this muſt be done,
And then ſhall laſt long, I, ſo it be won.
This Doctor is not yet ſufficient,
To giue a remedie to your patient.
This meſſenger for all his double diligence,
Shall diſpatch nothing well, nor of importance.
In ſéeking treaſure you loſe but your labour.
Like him that would catch a hare with a tabor.
This is not of good education.
Seeke out another of better faſhion.
O notorious nigard that to one poore mite,
He ſhall not imploy one pennie aright.
Let it not diſpleaſe that by the complexion,
The child ſhall be of a wilde condition.
According to thy nature as thou art inclined,
Many brawles and troubles to thee are aſſigned.
Preuent the worſt by diſcretion and wit,
And looſe not thy time with a fooliſh fit.
The heart on couetouſneſſe is ſo ſet,

He is in good health, luſtie and merrie,

This man hath wit good ſtore, knowledge, and ſcience,

Be ſure that fortune now will leaue thée,

The party abſent, and from you a ſtranger,

There will be wars daily, worſe and worſe,

Liue not in hope nor good expectation,

He ſhall enioy his loue, with endleſſe glée,

He for whom you now enquire is paſſing well,

This yéere with vs all troubles ſhall ſurceaſe,

This Phiſition is very learned and wiſe,

He ſhall doe his meſſage ſure and politicke,

There is treaſure ſtore, if it could be found,

He ſhall be of a good complexion ſurely,

If he haue done euill he muſt amend it.

His enemies ſhall be by him ouerthrowne,

Of your loue and deſires within ſhort ſpace,

He is wiſe, good, and full of honeſtie,

He will not performe what now you expect,

There is treaſure, that is ſure a plaine caſe,

To haue all things plentie, then ſtay here,

In all good things his imployment ſhall be,

She ſhall loue a man, wiſe, ſecret, and graue,

He ſhall in the end get credit ſuch ſtore,

Betweene his outward ſhow and his conſcience,

In the ſame place where it is ſaid to be,

Vndertake it not this weeke I you pray.

Thou ſhalt liue long in health, in wealth and eaſe,

Thou maiſt well riſe to great preferment.
He ſhall be excellent for courage and ſprite,
And in memory ſhall be his chiefe delite.
Follow ceaſe not, but be importunate,
And in the end thou ſhalt be fortunate.
There is ſeldome found in ſo great beauty,
A firme chaſte minde, with conſtant honeſtie.
There are many now that ſerue the King,
Still male content at euery thing.
Becauſe his mother hath made him a foole,
He neuer will proue to profit at the ſchoole.
You that thinke you are very well preferred,
Shall be eare long in your graue interred.
I thinke that by friends they ſhall agree,
And ſo liue together in amitie.
What ſo he points, is nothing worth,
Therefore I'le giue nothing in good ſooth.
This medicine is good and moſt excellent,
Take it then by the Doctors appointment.
Feare not this ill hap, for I thée aſſure,
It ſhall no harme to any man procure.
I know not who ſhould the ſame vnfold,
But in the end it will be told.
They both ſhall liue in loue without any hate,
Vntill for goods they fall at debate.
Forbeare a little, the better to aſſayle,
And then to get goods thou canſt not faile.
This child ſhall be paſſing apt, wiſe, and vpright,
Ingenious, ſtout, and of a good ſprite.
For a preſent ſpéed, and the beſt ſhift,
Is fréely to giue ſome good gift.
Thou art beloued, therefore it is iuſt
To ſhew thy ſelfe kind, for loue thou muſt.
It is beſt by ſeruice and behauiour,
To ſeeke to purchaſe loue and fauour.
He is ſo prompt, and of ſo good a wit,
That for a Secretarie he will be fit.
The youngeſt, and fineſt among you all,
Shall be ſicke, then dye, and ſo ſooneſt fall.
Both of them ſeeking for reuenge ſtill,
Are like to be in daunger and perill.
This aſſaylant ſhall haue the victorie,
And ſo obtaine both honour and glorie.
Suffer him not to take any blood,
But other Phiſicke will be verie good.
It is a letter of ordinarie ſort,
And therefore to no man is of import.
Thy faults were good to be concealed,
But they will at laſt with ſhame be reuealed.
Theſe two brethren for all their eſtate,
Shall neuer agree but liue in debate.
Thou ſhalt haue goods and riches competent,
And liue happie with good contentment.
He ſhall be of vnderſtanding and capable,
But his memorie ſhall be verie feeble.
It were better in time to quit it,
Then with trouble ſo long to ſollicit.
Becauſe thou art wiſe politicke and rich,
They will faune and flatter and loue thee much.
Enter not the Courtlike a prentiſe poore,
For the great the little doe ſtill deuoure.
I like it well ſo they imploy all thing,
In the end to get knowledge and learning.
Trouble not thy ſelfe for it is oft told,
That as ſoone goes the young ſhéepe as the old.
He among the reſt that is of leſt age,
Shall get aboue others great aduantage.
If they doe fight the quarrell to trie,
The defendant ſhall haue the victorie.
I will aduiſe you and this counſell giue,
Take héede and at no hand doe it beléeue.
This your letter containes ſuch ill géere,
As if neither pleaſant nor good to heare.
The thing will be diſcouered moſt plaine,
Therefore neuer expect the loſſe or gaine.
The two brethren of whom you ſo inquire,
Shall verie hardly agrée together.
By his couetouſneſſe and foolerie,
He ſhall fall to extreame pouertie.
Vnto this childe nature doth ordaine,
Excellent memorie and a quicke braine.
He that ſhall be a good ſoliciter,
Will get the iudgement in an houre.
Concerning this woman I am of the minde,
That at length to loue thée ſhe ſhall be inclinde.
To be in ſuch ſeruice thou canſt not léefe,
Being better then libertie by many degrees.
He ſhall prooue wiſer then other men,
Either to ſpeake well, or write with his pen.
He ſhall be gentile, and to vertue incline,
And for learning ſubiect to diſcipline.
Of theſe two friends the beſt and greater man,
Shall be the firſt dead doe what he can.
They haue no deſire to fight certaine,
For both are affraide and feare to be ſlaine.
If thou beeſt tender thou then maiſt forſake it,
And thy ſtomake not good at no hand take it.
Why ſhouldſt thou be angrie to hinder thy diet,
There is no cauſe but thou maiſt be quiet.
Thy ſecret is kept cloſe aſſure thy ſelfe,
For the man is prudent, and no babling elfe.
They are of good nature to peace inclinde,
And that they will loue, it is my minde.
Deſtinie hath ordaind thy fortune ſuch.
That beyond all meaſure thou ſhalt be rich.
Except nature deceiue me, he ſhall be wiſe,
Prudent, politicke, and moſt preciſe.
If the iudge ſéeme croſſe and be in a rage,
Then gould is beſt his furie to ſwage.
Retire thée then leaue and take my counſell,
Such loue is like a wet éele by the tayle.
Accept the ſeruice and be officious,
For it is good and will be proſperous.
If thou beeſt wiſe then maiſt thou beleeue me,
To kéepe thy owne houſe is beſt for thée,
It were not good but an vnfit thing,
To put this childe to any learning.
Draw cuts, for the beſt ſhall prooue worſt,
And he that drawes it ſhall die the firſt.
This ſwaggering ſwaine if his mallice extend,
Will be ſure to obtaine the worſe in the end.
This medicine which the Doctor doth ordaine,
If it be well mixt ſhall be good certaine.
His meſſage ſeacute;emes to be of ſuch import,
As preſages rather ſorrow then ſport.
It will be knowne though awhile it delay,
For a bablers tongue no man can well ſtay,
Theſe brothers are both of them to blame,
That to liue ſtill and loue they cannot frame.
By his extortion rich he ſhall grow,
But in th'end it ſhall melt away like ſnow.
This prettie one ſhall neuer trouble ſchoole,
But rather prooue a naturall foole.
Follow thy cauſe well if thou be wiſe,
For I ſee iuſtice hath blinded eies.
Retire thy ſelfe betime from his perſon,
For his loue will prooue to thee but treaſon.
Though thy loue be féeble and without remorce,
His loue reſts violent and of great force.
It is not for thée the readieſt way,
To ſerue in Court, marke what I ſay.
He is by nature a little obdure,
Yet prone to his booke, of this be thou ſure.
He that in this his fortune doth craue,
Is likelie the firſt to be in his graue.
Feare not how angrie ſo euer thou ſée them,
For I am ſure their friends wil agrée them.
This medicine being ſo laxatiue,
Will prooue to thee faſcheous and coraſiue.
Be bould, for it will prooue as good agen,
There is nothing equall to the loue of men.
This thing being ſecret and neuer knowne,
Is vnpoſſible euer to be ſhowne.
They ſhall as I thinke be each to other,
As kinde and louing as brother and brother.
There is great riches ſurely ment him.
Except ſome miſchance hap to preuent him.
He ſhall be good by his inclination,
But youthfull tricks, ſhalbe his deſtruction.
Without the lawyer get ſome preſent,
Your ſute will faile incontinent.
If thou wilt beléeue the oath of his partie,
No doubt but the quarrel wil then ſoone agrée.
He is well loued and ſo it ſhall prooue,
So long as there may be ſtill loue for loue.
As he goes forward he ſhall haue good lucke,
Seruing the welthy that haue ſtore of mucke.
I am perſwaded and that you ſhall ſée,
He will prooue apteſt to Philoſophie.
He that now ſéemes beſt in all your eyes,
A thouſand to one but firſt he dies.
The challenger is valiant and ſtout,
And will haue reuenge there is no doubt.
Take heede that what he appoints be not ſuch,
As by working it weaken you not to much.
There is no vrgent cauſe for ought I know,
Except ſome bargaine or monie I owe.
The thing may be ſecret huſht and ſtill,
And ſo knowne to none except you will.
Theſe two of ſeuerall humours ſhall be.
And yet for ſhame they both ſhall agrée.
Be nigardly ſtill and ſpare nere ſo much,
It is vnpoſſible thou ſhouldſt be rich.
He ſhall be ſo fantaſticke and ſo wilde,
As is not likely to be reconcilde.
He ſhall neuer, neither old nor young,
Obtaine to ſpeake with a flowing tongue.
By long ſeege and ſtaying a great ſort,
The enemie at laſt ſhall get the fort.
Hee loues thee well although he ſeeme ſtrange,
Yet ſhall his loue from thee neuer change.
He ſhall long raigne moſt maieſticall,
To the ioy and loue of his ſubiects all.
If ſleeping thy dreame force thee to awake,
It ſhewes ſome ſtrange thing I dare vndertake.
Reſt in good hope for thou maiſt be ſure,
That they that threaten thee liue in great feare.
Make no bargaine great or notable,
For it will not be to thee profitable.
He hath ſurfeted with eating ſomething,
That at the heart is his great payning.
I thee aduiſe to write all in verſe,
And with cloſe words thy minde to rehearſe.
This thy purpoſe, as I vnderſtand.
Is like to haue an vnlucky end.
He that his brother leaſt enuie doth beare,
Is like to liue long and many a yéere.
A ſchollers flat cap will fit him beſt,
To get a benefice among the reſt.
By diligent labour and carefull paine,
Great ſtore of wealth and good thou ſhalt obtaine.
He ſhall temper his ſpéech mildly with ſkill,
And ſo ſtill liue quiet, go where he will.
Some good agréement the campe ſhall diſcharge,
So all men ſhall retire and go at large.
His kindneſſe is naught worth, and but a bable,
Becauſe his heart is falſe and variable.
He ſhall liue and raigne long moſt happily.
Except by ſome exceſſe he ſurfet and dye.
Thy pleaſant dreame with contentation,
Hath none effect or ſignification.
Thou art too timerſome, and ſoone diſmaid,
A very ſmall thing will make thee afraid.
Though that you intend nothing for to buy,
Yet I you aduiſe to goe ſpéedily.
That which makes him ſo ſore languiſh and pine,
Is that he hath taſted of loues ſwéet wine.
Lay by thy writing, and be not afraid,
And put thou no truſt in a chamber maid.
This buſineſſe ſhall haue a good end,
For Fortune is graciouſly thy friend.
It is no matter who firſt die or fall,
For ere it be long, death will haue all.
They both are in danger, therefore kéepe watch,
For death doth intend, them both to diſpatch.
Let him labour and toyle neuer ſo much,
It will be in vaine he ſhall not be rich.
He ſhall ſpeake brauely with many faire ſhowes,
But his ſpéech ſhal be weake & witleſſe God knowes.
This fort ſhall be had without any faile,
If that ſome braue ſouldier chance it to aſſaile.
There can no good come, as the caſe now ſtands,
If thou put thy credit into his hands.
This king ſhall not laſt or endure long,
For the enemies purſuite is very ſtrong.
What in the day I haue thought on by chance,
In the night my dreames doe ſtill it aduance.
Thou art too affraide of euerie ſmall thing,
None walks in a field that feares each leafe ſtirring.
Whatſoeuer now to buie thou art bent,
Thou ſhalt be ſure with loſſe to repent.
It is not fortune that now I diſcouer,
But a woman that faine would haue thée loue her.
Put thou no other writing in vre,
Thy ſelfe muſt ſée it, of this be ſure.
Whatſoeuer meanes thou doſt intend,
Thou ſhalt haue ſmall pleaſure in the end.
Feare not, you haue no cauſe at all to doubt,
For I am ſure the end will fall well out.
He ſhall liue longeſt that is moſt chaſt,
For that his bodie he doth not waſt.
If thou a woman canſt content and pleaſe,
Thou ſhalt obtaine wealth though but little eaſe.
By ieſts and pleaſant ſpéeches now and then.
Thou ſhalt get fauour of great noble men.
Th' enemie ſhall not obtaine their deſire,
But malecontent, diſgrac't they ſhall retire.
His true loue and fauour is not very common,
For though he ſéeme friendly he loues but one.
This King he ſhall raigne and liue verie long,
But cruell to his ſubiects doing them wrong.
Concerning thy dreame I am of the minde,
It is of import as a puffe of winde.
Concerning this feare in verie ſhort ſpace,
There will be meanes found to alter the caſe.
Buie while they offer you good condition,
For oft time loſſe doth follow omiſſion.
Thou néedſt not for the lot to ſéeke redreſſe,
But for the ſpirit that doth him poſſeſſe.
By meſſage there hath béene wrought ſuch a tricke,
As hath made the woman come at a becke.
If thou canſt finde no better a meane,
The leaſt thou canſt doe is to write a •• ine.
Although the courſe ſéeme not very lowable,
Yet ſhall the end be verie honourable.
We ſée it by proofe and euerie day,
That often the youngeſt goes firſt away.
By thy great ſtudie I muſt confeſſe,
Thou haſt thy wealth with great happineſſe.
He ſhall ſpeake better with ſkill and good grace,
Then the lawyer can, concerning the caſe.
The fort that now is ſo beſéeged round,
Shall be ſackt and ſpoilde and thrown to the ground,
Th'art loued, what loue can doe, thou wants not ought.
Therefore be glad, reioyce, and take no thought.
In honours bed he rather ſhall die,
Then to be taken diſhonourably.
This dreame hath no ſignification,
Therefore he is a foole that thinkes thereon.
He cannot reſt quiet where ſo he doth lie,
But ſtill is afraide without cauſe why.
Whether you intend to buie or to ſell,
Doe nothing therein without good counſell.
It is a melancolious extaſie,
That in the end will bréed an apoplexie.
If he be well puniſht t'is for his ill,
And 〈◊〉 us fortune that helpes him theretill.
Loue-letters found doth ſecrets bewray,
They'r fooles that truſt them if otherwiſe they may.
If th'enterpriſe be guided true,
A verie good end there will enſue.
He that hath moſt good of treaſure and ſtore,
Shall die firſt, leaue all, and goe before.
Thou ſhalt get thée, by great Lords acquaintance,
Of treaſure ſtore and goods great abundance.
This childe ſhall ſpeake well with comely cariage,
And in his geſture moſt ſéemely mannage.
If the fort be vitled though they aſſaile,
They ſhall neuer get it but by battaile.
Take no care nor be not ielous,
And of the other be not ſuſpitious.
This gouernement is but euill begun,
And to increaſe it nought will be won.
This dreame importeth and would be wrought on,
And doth deſerue wiſely to be thought on.
He ſhall in ſurety be re'ſtabliſht againe,
And ſo by friendſhip remitted, remaine.
Neither buie nor ſell now as you pretend,
For then you ſhall rue it ſore in the end.
Thou canſt thy ſelfe better no way aduiſe,
Then to imploy thy time in marchandiſe.
He is neither poſſeſt of ſpirit nor diuell,
But too long conceald a ſecret euill.
Who ſo puts his truſt to inke and paper,
To loſe his loue doth put in aduenture.
The firſt, the midſt, the laſt, and all the meanes,
Shall ſtill be croſt with great inconuenience.
He ſhall thinke that he ſuffers great wrong,
Becauſe for the end he thinketh long.
Thou ſhalt be wealthie, but yet at the laſt,
Poore man, thy faire ſun-ſhine cleane ouercaſt.
Whatſoeuer you doe t'is all but vaine,
He ſhall haue no good grace, nor yet ſpeake plaine.
It ſhall be ſubdued or ere it be long,
By ſuttletie or force although it be ſtrong.
Your friend is not ſo light nor apt to range,
Nor hath no will for another to change.
Although he be gentile ſoft and of good grace,
Yet ſhall he not laſt nor ſtay in his place.
If with iudgement this dreame you doe expound,
The truth and meaning is eaſily found.
If he be afraide let him then not ceaſe,
To make himſelfe ſafe by a iuſtice of peace.
Thou art ſo fearefull and full of doubt,
That thou ſhalt ſcarce keepe thee from the ſtrong rout.
I ſay, buy not, whatſoeuer doe befall.
For what ſo thou buyeſt thou ſhalt loſe it all.
He is attainted for a notable witch,
Which will him danger & trouble him much.
It were farre better, if thou wilt doe well,
Not for to ſend, but thy owne meſſage tell,
The thing of which thou wouldeſt vnderſtand,
Doth not ſeeme likely to haue a good end.
He that is moſt loath, and moſt couetous,
Is moſt ſure to die the firſt before vs.
If thou meane to ſerue and take any paine,
The end ſhall prooue good with profit and gaine.
In ſhow and in ſpeech he ſhall be gracious,
But once moued, prooue moſt audacious.
Thoſe that doe keepe it are ſo faint hearted,
That it ſhall be won, and their goods parted.
He loues thee little and but to halues,
You know, change of paſture makes fat calues.
He may continue and raigne a ſmall while,
But at laſt he ſhall runne into exile.
Your dreame is moſt vaine and meerely but folly,
Therefore take heart, and be not melancollie.
This dreame is too true though th'effect be not paſt,
And though't be not yet, it will be at laſt.
Be not afraid though they ſéeme great fighters,
For, commonly, barkers are no great biters.
The time, the place, and alſo the ſeaſon,
Prognoſticates profit with good reaſon.
Aſſure thy ſelfe, that to thy diſaduance,
Thou ſhalt, for this time, haue no ill chance.
A faithfull louer will ſtill be afraid,
Leaſt his loues ſecrets ſhould be bewraid.
Hap what hap may, or let be as it is,
At laſt I am ſure 'twill not come amiſſe.
That he ſhould liue longeſt it ſéemes moſt fit,
Who to preſerue his health hath the moſt wit.
Be diligent, wiſe, and haue a good heart,
So ſhalt thou of riches haue a good part.
He ſhall be affable, graue, wiſe, and kinde,
So that hardly you ſhall ſuch another finde.
The Cat that loues ſweet milke had neede beware,
And he as wiſe that meanes to ſhunne the ſnare.
I loue thee well with heart I thee aſſure,
Then loue thou me, and let thy loue endure.
The King that hath his heartie Subiects loue,
Is happie here but bleſſed more aboue.
Let him take héede that he may long be ſpared,
For why his vnfriends, already are prepared.
Beléeue you nothing what you haue dreamed,
For all is lies not to be eſtéemed.
Thou haſt great feare and not without ſome cauſe,
But in ſhort while thou ſhalt be ſure at eaſe.
Buie thou nothing now, but looke well about,
For it is not likely to fall well out.
Beleeue the ſudden healing of this harme,
Appeares to be done by ſome diuelliſh charme.
Send no meſſage as I ſaid before,
For your owne ſpeech ſhall effect much more.
Aduiſe you well of this ſame matter,
For t'is ill inclinde, I doe not flatter.
He that for another hath digged a pit,
May well chaunce himſelfe to fall in it.
By thy great expence each day and houre,
Thou ſhalt neuer be rich but euer poore.
Thy gibing and ieſting no good affords,
But to wrong others by thy idle words.
By famine and ſword a meane ſhall be found,
To ruine this place, and race it to ground.
On this fained friend ſet not thy heart,
For he onely, but ſcorneth for his part.
Thou haſt a loyall friend that loues thée much,
Therefore thou art bound to him to be ſuch.
This King hath raignd prudently and with ſkil,
So God preſerue him if it be his will.
This ſame ſtrange dreame of which you now enquire.
Vnto ſome great wonder is like to aſpire.
Be not afraide, yet ſtand well on thy gard,
For all will ſure to ruine afterward.
The time is now verie well inclinde,
To any trade that thou haſt a minde.
It is not chaunce whatſoeuer ſome ſay,
But naturall ſickneſſe, as ſee you may.
Write darke miſticall ſhort and ſuttlely,
And ſend by a craftie fellow priuily.
If wiſely you carrie the matter ſtill,
Be ſure that haue a good end it will.
They are in no danger nor perill at all,
Except by exceſſe they ſurfet and fall.
If thou thy doings canſt prudently guide,
Then ſhall great riches, and wealth thee betide.
He ſhall in ſpéech be moſt curteous and kinde,
And beare withall a true generous minde.
The incloſed are ſo ſtrong, bould, and ſtoute,
That of the aſſailants, they neither feare nor doubt.
They ſhall not keepe long, nor be able to ſheelde.
But forc't, and content the fortreſſe to yeelde.
Thou haſt a good friend, that ſure doth thee backe,
And will not let thee by any meanes lacke.
This king may himſelfe moſt certaine aſſure.
He ſhall ere long haue a ſucceſſure.
Beleeue what thou wilt, being vp or in bed,
This dreame is like to put thee in great dred.
Be of courage, and reſolute, I ſay,
And let no kinde of feare thy heart diſmay.
It were not amiſſe to part it, and then,
To buy thee ſome poſſeſſion againe.
It is neither lot nor incantation,
But meerely a fooliſh imagination.
If ſhe can write and reade, it then were better,
By ſome good friend to ſend her a letter.
Purſue, attempt, and be importunate,
The braueſt mindes are ſtill moſt fortunate.
He that his ſtudie doth follow the beſt,
God will preferre him before all the reſt.
Fall to ſpeedily, and be not afraide,
Thou ſhalt be rich by marchandiſe and trade.
He ſhall haue tongue that neuer ſhall lie ſtill,
But yet neuer a wiſe word ſpeake he will.
He ſhall not preuaile in learning at all,
Being of a rude wit, and ruſticall.
For thy honour, what ſo ere come to paſſe,
Be thou reuenged of that diſgrace.
The loue, be you ſure, ſhall neuer haue end,
That is proteſted by ſo good a friend.
This King is good and of great dexteritie,
Vpright, and ſhall doe to all men equitie.
This dream which ſo much doth thée miſtemper,
Doth preſage ill lucke and miſaduenture.
He ſhall haue good fortune, and ſo at no ſeaſon
Be in any danger to die by poyſon.
Ceaſe, be wiſe, and quarrell thou not therefore,
For this is the laſt, and there ſhall be no more.
If this witneſſe be vſed curteouſly,
He is like to tell more then the verity.
By the Father the thing may well be wrought,
If he will haue a childe that ſhal prooue ought.
Though by the childe done it was neuer,
Tis beſt to beleeue him how ſo euer.
For all their valour, brags, and forwardneſſe,
They ſhall purchaſe neither honour nor riches.
Neuer doe hope, for neither young nor olde.
Thou ſhalt not get riches, ſiluer or gould.
Thou ſhalt be happie, and to great wealth riſe,
In ſpight of all thy vnkinde enemies.
By his inclination he ſhall be wittie,
Therefore if he ſhould not learne it were pittie.
Put thy cauſe to God as the caſe now ſtands,
And he will reuenge it without thy hands.
This loue ſhall ceaſe and be no more amitie,
By a moſt diſhoneſt fault and infamie.
This King ſhall take counſell and follow the ſame,
So all his deſignes ſhall paſſing well frame.
Looke well to thy ſelfe, be vigilant ſtill,
Dreames are not ſo oft good as they be'ill.
Take thou héede of thy daily companion,
For he may well prooue to giue thée poyſon.
This thing recouer it againe thou ſhall,
Not onely in part, but obtaine it all.
He is vpright, iuſt, and moſt equitable,
And all his other parts are moſt notable.
That ſhall be ſure to haue the chiefe deſire,
Which is, good ſtore of children, as they require.
You may ſoone perceiue by his lookes and fauour,
Who begot him, and is his right father.
They ſhall obtaine goods great plentie and ſtore,
But yet few friends to loue them therefore.
If the eldeſt his fortune doe enquire,
It ſhall be good as to his owne deſire.
If thou doſt not venter and put to triall,
Thou ſhalt not be rich I make deniall.
Doe what you will he ſhall be a ſouldier,
And neuer proue fit to be a ſcholler.
To be reuenged hope thou not at all,
For thy meanes is too weake, and too too ſmall.
The end will not prooue to thee commendable,
For both th'one and the other is veritable.
Conteſt not with him for it is but vaine,
He will doe nothing but of his owne braine.
Thy dreame doth giue to thée good aſſurance,
To liue ſtill in hope and firme eſperance.
For to be affraid you haue good reaſon,
And take you héed of a falſe knaue or treaſon.
Hereafter looke you well vnto the reſt,
That it be not loſt too, that is your beſt.
This ſhall to you the beſt and worſt ſtill tell,
Therefore be wiſe and take to you good counſell.
They are not well matched, but of an ill kinde,
To get any children this is my minde.
The father muſt not be angry in minde,
Although an ill anſwere here be aſſign'd.
His mother that brought him vp from the firſt,
Can the trueſt tell, his beſt and his worſt.
If the puney will good preferment haue,
He muſt to the Court, and there be ſtill braue.
He ſhall be rich with good proſperitie,
If he would but leaue his wanton letcherie.
Put him to ſeruice, for that is the beſt,
But not to his learning, of all the reſt.
Of all the iniuries, trouble, griefe, and paine,
That they haue done, he ſhall reuenge againe.
This now new friendſhip grounded from the heart,
Shall neuer be broke, till death them doe part.
This King is fit, a Monarke for to be,
For he loues God, Iuſtice, and equitie.
This dreame proceedes from a vaine idleſkull,
And in the end ſhall of danger be full.
Take thou no thought, nor feare not yet to dye,
Thy end ſhall not come ſo ſoon nor ſuddenly.
The thiefe you ſhall get, if with ſpéed you follow,
With ſearch, hue and cry, ſhoute, ſeeke and hollow.
This witnes is a very honeſt man,
It can doe no harme, what ſo he ſaith than.
They ſhall obtaine, ſo that the good wife,
Doe her beſt, and goodwill all the daies of her life.
To haue ſonnes and daughters be not affraid,
For to ingender you are both well made.
It is moſt ſure, it hath had a father,
But who it is none knowes except the mother.
The eldeſt ſhall obtaine by his wife.
good fortune and wealth all daies of his life.
Thou ſhalt haue riches and great promotion,
When thou in thy minde doeſt leaſt dreame thereon.
If he follow ſtudie in his young age,
He ſhall riſe to honour, and great perſonage.
Some are ſo haſtie to reuenge their ſhame,
That they augment diſgrace, with a worſe name.
The friendſhip that is by bribes obtained,
Doth not laſt long, becauſe it was fained.
He ſhall in all places keepe them in awe,
Obſeruing true Iuſtice, according to Lawe.
This dreame pretendeth good very much,
That the dreamer ſhall be happie and rich.
If thou then doſt feare any poiſoning,
Out of thy owne houſe eate no kind of thing.
For any loſſe had either great or ſmall,
Pine not thy heart, for then thou pineſt all.
This witneſſe may chance to prattle too much,
He cannot diſſemble he is none ſuch.
This witneſſe for the thing that you deſire,
ſhall tell the truth, of what ſo you require.
They ſhall haue children ſtore, all in good time,
Before they haue paſt of youth their chiefe prime.
He demands nor ſéekes I ſée no further,
But that you remaine to him a father.
If this youth at firſt well inſtructed be,
He ſhall in time riſe to great authoritie.
When all ioy and pleaſure ſeeme to be paſt,
Then ſhall thy good fortune come on moſt faſt.
He hath a good wit, and employd may be,
Either in the Church or in the laitie.
Truth doth not euer beare the greateſt ſway,
for often the beaten doth pay the afray.
Their loue is but vaine and all volupty,
A humour that ſtill doth follow beauty.
He ſhall his Subiects loue, and very well pleaſe,
By taxes, and tributes, that he ſhall eaſe.
This ſumme your dreame, if you doe way it well,
Doth enemies, and many miſchiefes tell.
Th'are in no danger, I ſweare by cod foxe,
Of no kinde of poiſon, except the poxe.
Forget the thing loſt, and be not ſo ſad,
That will not returne, which cannot be had.
To be each where well ſought you muſt procure,
And then for to finde it you ſhall be ſure.
All that he doth know he ſurely will tell,
If that you examine him verie well.

I know it will be what
• eare is ſaid,
If you be not too late and they diſmaide.
The mother is wife and hath not miſdone,
It is onely the fathers condition.
The eldeſt ſhall haue verie great alliance,
And of verie great men the countenance.
Temper thy youthfull inclination,
If thou wilt aſpire to reputation.
This will be ſure good for no kinde of trade,
Twere better that he a Churchman were made.
It were thy beſt to God to recommend thee,
For none can better protect or defend thee.
Such king of loues ſhall neuer faile them,
But death will be ſure for to aſſaile them.
That king cannot rule, but is in ill caſe,
That ſaileth ſo by euerie mans compaſſe.
This dreame if well you doe it vnderſtand,
Declares that you ſhall haue what you demand.
If you forbeare diet to eate or drinke.
You ſhall be out of danger as I thinke.
If you prooue rich, wealthie, and opulent,
Then ſée that of your health you be vigilent.
Take you no care for the worſt is paſt by,
Elſe I am deceiued, and tell you a lie.
I vnderſtand not that anie thing is ment,
That will ſerue thy turne to any intent.
The woman is drie and yet moſt actiue,
And ſhall neuer haue childe to liue aliue.
This child ſhall be I know not yet well what,
Onely I am ſure his father him begot.
Good fortune ſhall you ſure greatly aduance,
By a good turne that vnlooked for ſhall chance.
It will be late notwithſtanding all art,
Ere thou get goods from anie part.
This childe will neuer to learning incline,
Therefore to fortune you muſt it propine.
Thou ſhalt put thy ſelfe in danger by it,
And yet not be able to reuenge it.
This amitie ſo vndiſcréetely done,
Shall not continue, but haue an end ſoone.
Vnder the ſhadow of doing iuſtice,
He ſhall obtaine to great place and office.
This ſtrang dreame wherewith troubled thou haſt bin.
Preſageth the death of ſome of thy kinne.
This thy dreame to me doth plainely preſage,
Of ſome of thy néere kinne a mariage.
Be not thou in feare there's none ſéekes thy life,
T'is but ſome vnfriend that ſéekes to ſet ſtrife.
Thinke it no loſſe for as I vnderſtand,
The recouery ſhall be ſoone and eaſily found.
This ſhall tell the truth without anie charme,
Yet would he be loath to doe any harme.
They ſhall haue children and doe verie well,
Whoſe beautie and good fortune ſhall excell.
The father may well adopt it his ſonne,
He is in all points ſo like of condition.
The younger by his labour and ſeruice,
Shall be ſure to get a good benefice.
Both young and old you ſhall be moſt happie,
Poſſeſſing pleaſure, and verie wealthie.
He ſhall be apt to reade, and bookes to ſearch,
And therefore right fit to ſerue in the Church.
You may well with honour and credit ſéeke,
To haue a reuenge if ſo you doe like.
But death onely their loyall loues may end,
For nothing elſe ſhall euer them offend.
He ſhall raigne iuſt without all villanie,
Pitifull to the good without all tyrannie.
This King ſhall be good and of a great minde,
And to his ſubiects gentle and kinde.
This thy pleaſant dreame in his right nature,
Doth ſignifie ſome ill and ſtrange aduenture.
Thou art afraide of trecherous poyſoning,
Thy greateſt ſafety is to kéepe waking.
Of this fortune no farther doe enquire,
For I can ſay nothing to thy deſire.
This witneſſe vrged, and rightly vnderſtood,
Is like to ſay ill, but nought to thy good.
This woman is not matched verie well,
To haue any increaſe, this I can tell.
The father knowes it beſt, when all is done,
Whether that or no, it be his owne ſonne.
He that moſt his booke and learning doth ply,
Shall after liuelong and moſt happily.
Fortune can him no way to riches lift,
Becauſe ſpending he is ſuch an vnthrift.
You are abuſed, and therefore now hearke,
He ſhall neuer attaine to be ſcoller or clarke.
If for thy wrongs amends they doe offer,
Take my aduiſe, refuſe not their proffer.
By the diſſoluteneſſe of this thy friend,
This your great loue ſhall ſoone be brought to end.
This amitie begun while each hath breath,
Shall no way be diſſolued, but by death.
He ſhall raigne and rule in great equitie,
And liue and die in great felicitie.
Who thinketh of ill doth dreame of the ſame,
For an ill nature is neuer in good frame.
Thou haſt too too feminine a faint heart,
That onely feare of poyſoning doth make thée ſtart.
Trouble not your ſelfe for the thing gone,
It ſhall be found out and brought backe anone.
This ſhall tell truth before all be ended.
But ſome by his words ſhall be ſore offended.
The father like a man hath plaid his part,
And ſhall haue manie children for his deſart.
Each one that is wiſe muſt néedes eaſily know,
That ſure it is his, and I too ſay ſo.
The yongeſt ſhall be wiſe and prouident,
And nothing like the other, negligent.
Thy forward ſpirit perſwades thée of truth,
That thou ſhalt haue great riches in thy youth.
He ſhall neuer poſſeſſe abilitie
Either to trafficke or any ſtudie.
To diſſemble a while put thou in vre,
He is not ouercome that doth endure.
The time ſhall fit thée or ere it be long,
To haue due reuenge of this thy great wrong.
This loue ſhall laſt long without ſuſpition,
If they can liue quiet with diſcretion.
Vnder his grace and royall maieſtie,
All his ſubiects ſhall liue moſt quietly.
This dreame which ſo much doth trouble thée ſtill,
Beléeue, importeth neither good nor well.
He is ſubtill, and wiſe, and knowes which way,
To take a good courſe without all delay.
He that cunningly ſéekes vnto the end,
In bréefe he ſhall the partie eaſely finde.
He is craftie I diſcerne by his noſe,
And will ſay little troth as I ſuppoſe.
They ſhall haue children, for both loue letcherie,
And their barnes ſhall be inclind to trechery.
Beléeue it you may, and be not diſmaide,
For all is true the mother hath ſaid.
The youngeſt of all, by his iudgement ſound,
Shall be rich, and gaine him ten thouſand pound.
So ſoone as thou firſt doſt take any paines,
Thy houſe ſhal be fild with profit and gaines.
If he could be brought to follow learning,
It were for him the beſt and onely thing.
Cauſe him to goe and learne at grammer ſchoole,
For he ſhall prooue a ſcholler, and no foole.
He is arreſted vpon ſuſpition,
And again releaſt on ſmal condition.
The femals loue is moſt conſtant and true,
But his is not ſuch, I dare well tell you.
This King ſhall be ſerued with feare and loue,
For ſo his royall déedes doe him approoue.
As I vnderſtand by this lots pretence,
Thou maiſt doe thy buſines with diligence.
It is no poyſon charme or witcherie,
But onely a ſickneſſe of infirmitie.
There is no ſuch ſport as to hunt and chaſe,
And follow the game to th'end of the race.
He ſhall neuer be quiet for ought I can ſée,
Giue credit to this, and beléeue you me.
I beleeue that they both beyond exceſſe,
Are greatly inclind to couetouſneſſe.
Liue he, or die he, take you no great care,
For of all his goods you ſhall haue no ſhare.
Seeke yet againe farther for true it is,
I am not now verie well pleaſd with this.
Neither by deſtinie, vertue, nor art,
Thou ſhalt not obtaine of wealth to haue part.
He ſhall haue of goods great plentie and ſtore,
Or elſe this his fortune doth lie the more.
Euerie profeſſion that's honeſt and true,
Shall fit his humour I dare aſſure you.
In bréefe he is like to be ſet at large,
By ſome friends that will vndergoe the charge.
Vnto this louer I muſt giue great blame,
For his ſo too couldly louing the dame.
Among his ſubiects he ſhall be eſtéemed,
Becauſe to doe well he is not aſhamed.
Of this preſage there is at all no doubt,
But that in th'end it will fall well out.
He is ſicke, and no poyſon doth harme him,
Therefore giue Phiſicke, & ſéeke not to charme him.
T'is better in th'aire then in the woodes to range,
And ſo will the ſport be pleaſant and ſtrange.
He ſhall ſoone againe his libertie haue,
In ſpight of his foes that otherwiſe craue.
There is ſome cauſe if the woman make ſtay,
For otherwiſe there would be no delay.
The man that dying will make ſtay for none,
Is like to goe hence by himſelfe alone.
He loues thée well, but thou deſerueſt not all,
Be thou then to him faithfull and loyall.
In him there is at all no confidence,
Therefore put thou in him no aſſurance.
All that euer by Art he doth obtaine,
By great folly he ſpends the ſame againe.
Phyſicke is his ſole chiefe delight indéede,
For that is the Science hee moſt doth reede.
Twill be very hard a way for to finde,
To get him libertie, this is my minde.
The one doth loue well, ſo much I deſcry,
The other loues too, but 'tis but to lye.
He ſhall of his Subiects be loued euermore,
Becauſe he increaſeth their treaſure & ſtore.
I plaine perceiue, by this preſent preſage,
That it intendeth thy loſſe and damage.
A preſeruatiue you needs muſt giue him,
If you of poiſon, intend to relieue him.
Tis great pleaſure in the Forreſt to ſee,
