The contrarie partie, he is ſo great,
That hardly he will his libertie get.
The huſband is wonderfully too hot,
So the wife muſt ſtay, till a time may be got.
To diſpoſe his geare, it is great reaſon,
For now to depart, 'tis almoſt ſeaſon.
If he keepe himſelfe from exceſſes fit,
He may liue very long and not die yet.
The friend that thou didſt get, and laſt obtaine,
Shall loue thée ſure beſt, and be moſt certaine.
Such ſtrange aduenture ſhall vnto him chance,

His inclination, ſpirit, and minde,
Is all and onely to muſicke inclin'd.
He ſhall carrie himſelfe ſo well and wiſely,
That he ſhall ſoone come forth at libertie.
Theſe two louers ſo farre as I can ſee,
Aſſociate in loue and amitie.
This King the patterne of liberalitie,
Beloued is of the communaltie.
I ſée that this thy demand doth pretend,
Or ere it be long, the death of ſome friend.
Of poiſon giuen him he doth not dye,
Yet how he came by it, I know not truely.
Theſe Damſels deſire, no other delight,
Then in the high ſoaring faulcons flight.
A good louing friend, ſhall him ſo ſuſtaine,
That in the end he ſhall returne againe.
The damme is daintie, yet 'tis not her fault,
But her owne good mans, if ſhe turne to naught.
He may her well court, and the damſell woo,
The diuell a thing, ſhe will let him doe.
This ſhall liue long in health aſſuredly,
And then his naturall death he ſhall dye.
His loue is true, and of honeſt intent,
Himſelfe zealous and very continent.
By a fine wit, ſlight, cunning, Art, and ſkill,
Obtaine great riches ſurely he will.
He loues Philoſophy, and of each thing,
To know the effect, is his ſtudying.
He is ſo hated, as cannot be told,
Which will ſticke by him, vntill he be old.
The louers heart is wauering, and doth ſore,
But ſhe for courage, is a great deale more.
His ſubiects with eaſe, may ioifully ſing,
And euery day ſay God ſaue our good King.
Take thou no-pleaſure to know the effect,
For of moſt vile ſhame, it doth thee detect.
Some by ill will, hath done him ſo great wrong,
As will be his ſpoile, and ſticke by him long.
Th'one and the other are very good ſport,
And yet for to hunt is greateſt comfort.
Alas his daies will ſoone be at an end,
Except God ſend him the help of a friend.
Finally, he ſhal yet once againe be,
Recalled with credit honourably.
Let not the poore man ſuſtaine all the blame,
The fault is his good wiues, that is his dame.
Tis not vnlikely, but long he may liue.
If hee'll take as good counſell, as he can giue.
Thou maiſt loue him well, for who can ſay nay,
But how he loues thée, I nothing can ſay.
He commands fortune, what will you haue more,
Fate hath ordaind him, great plenty and ſtore.
If he were not faint-hearted I could ſay,
He might proue a Doctor, another day.
I am of the minde moſt aſſuredly,
That in ſhort ſpace he ſhall haue libertie.
The louer is moſt conſtant, firme, and true,
But ſhe I know is of another hue.
He ſhall be gracious, and ſwéet to looke on,
And ſo be beloued of euery one.
This ſigne it preſageth great ioy and glee,
And ſo a good houre which God ſend thee.
It is not poiſon, or any ſuch thing,
But wanton luſt, which youth doth daily ſting.
It is a pleaſure, which I muſt commend,
To continue a courſe vnto the end.
It is a great pleaſure to ſee dogges that be comming,
In a long courſs to take a Hare running.
As a baniſhed man he may ſoiourne,
For he is likely neuer to returne.
The damme is not blameable I know,
For ſhe hath done the duetie ſhe doth owe,
He ſhall liue out well, to natures beſt courſe,
And though ſome liue longer, it is the worſe.
This though he ſeeme very amiable,
Yet ſhall his loue be very mutable.
Thou ſhalt haue goods ſtore, and great abundance,
By thy good indeauours and prouidence.
Let him ſtudie on ſtill, that doth not paſſe,
For all his learning hee'll proue but an aſſe.
This odde creker, will finde out ſome ſtrange way,
To get himſelfe out, and yet nothing pay.
A thouſand turnes he proueth for her ſake,
And ſhe full as many doth for him make.
This King ſhall be victorious and great,
Which ſhall his Subiects hearts with ioy repleat.
What thou haſt ſeene is preſage of abuſe,
Yet with diſcretion make thereof good vſe.
This troubleſome winde, ſhall ſoone weare away,
And then thy health ſhall encreaſe day by day.
He hath eaten or drunke, or done ſome exceſſe,
Which is the onely cauſe of this ſickneſſe.
This gentle faulcon hath a moſt braue heart,
T'is a pleaſure to ſee him play his part.
Neuer thinke nor hope that thou ſhalt him ſee,
Enioy and haue all his goods quietly.
Neither thou nor the other doe their beſt,
Either to receiue, or furniſh the reſt.
His vitall ſprites are cooled all ſo much,
That death very ſhortly, his life ſhall tuch.
You muſt loue, if you beloued will be,
Or elſe your fault each one will eaſily ſee.
There is no hope of his good lucke at all,
Neither by ſkill or Arts Mecanicall.
He ſhall ſtill employ all his beſt ſtudie,
In the true knowledge of Philoſophy.
If ſome other chance, come not of more worth,
It will be this ſennight, ere he come forth.
Their loues often change of contrarie minde,
For ſhe is more variable then the winde.
The King is well loued, and of Maieſtie,
That on his poore Subiects hath loue and pittie.
This fearefull preſage that makes thee ſo afraid,

Fortune is fauouring, and thy good friend,

Beléeue me, for all this his extreame fit,

In haukes and hounds, is pleaſure for a King,

I know he ſhall ere long remitted be,

She is ready to take, and loth to leaue,
And yet for all that, ſtill hard to conceiue.
He deſires life ſtill, if that it might be,

This good fellow, of whom thou doeſt enquire,

Thy lucke aboue others, is farre excelling,

He ſhall haue more pleaſure in toyes and fooling,

They both loue truely, and with affection,

Make thou no great account of this preſage,

This hath, or I am much deceiued,

The one is too cold, the other too hot,

In this thy friend, there is ſuch defect,

He ſhall be poore, and in miſerable eſtate,

In this preſage, and in a moſt good houre,

He ſhall haue fortune in the beſt degree,

All ſciences that are delectable,

This poyſon ſeemeth to me verie ſtrange,

I can ſay nothing, for ought that I ſee,

Take my aduiſe, doe any thing begin,

This is a good time for anie to prooue,
